description: Engineers and scientists create and lead great companies, hiring managers when and where needed to help execute their vision. Designed expressly for students having a keen interest in technological innovation, this course investigates the roles of inventors and founders in successful technology ventures. Through case studies and guest speakers, we introduce the knowledge and skills needed to recognize and seize a high-tech entrepreneurial opportunity - be it a product or service - and then successfully launch a startup or spin-off company. The course studies key areas of intellectual property, its protection and strategic value; opportunity analysis and concept testing; shaping technology driven inventions into customer-driven products; constructing defensible competitive strategies; acquiring resources in the form of capital, people and strategic partners; and the founder's leadership role in an emerging high-tech company. Throughout the course emphasis is placed on decisions faced by founders, and on the sequential risks and determinants of success in the early growth phase of a technology venture. The course is designed for, but not restricted to, students of engineering and applied science and assumes no prior business education.

Throughout the course, emphasis is placed on decisions faced by founders, and on the sequential risks and determinants of success in the early growth phase of a technology venture.

Students enjoyed the content of the course. They thought the cases were interesting to read and the guest speakers added to the course with their first-hand experience. One said it was “one of the most useful courses I have taken at Penn” and another had “no doubt the knowledge gained from this course will be useful beyond my stay at Penn”.

Students thought Professor Babin was an excellent instructor. They enjoyed the atmosphere of learning and one remarked on his “tremendous amount of energy”.

Students reported learning a lot from the course, noting that the coursework was comprehensive. This course is designed for, but not restricted to, students of engineering and applied science and assumes no prior business education.
